title: Lodi Academy
text:
Lodi Academy (LA) is a co-educational <a href="Seventh-day%20Adventist">Seventh-day Adventist</a> private school located in <a href="Lodi%2C%20California">Lodi, California</a>. Lodi Academy, first known as the Western Normal Institute, opened its doors as a boarding school in 1908. Professor E. D. Sharpe served as the first President. In 1968, Lodi Academy became a day school. Lodi Academy is part of the Northern California Conference of Seventh-day Adventist Church. It is a part of the <a href="Seventh-day%20Adventist%20education">Seventh-day Adventist education system</a>, the world's second largest Christian school system.
Lodi Academy is recognized by the <a href="University%20of%20California">University of California</a> as an approved college preparatory secondary school, and it is accredited by the Seventh-day Adventist Board of Regents and the <a href="Western%20Association%20of%20Schools%20and%20Colleges">Western Association of Schools and Colleges</a>.
Academics.
The required curriculum includes classes in the following subject areas: Religion, English, Oral Communications, Social Studies, Mathematics, Science, Physical Education, Health, Computer Applications, Fine Arts, and Electives.
Spiritual aspects.
All students take religion classes each year that they are enrolled. These classes cover topics in <a href="Bible">biblical</a> history and <a href="Christianity">Christian</a> and <a href="Religious%20denomination">denominational</a> doctrines. Instructors in other disciplines also begin each class period with prayer or a short devotional thought, many which encourage student input. Weekly, the entire student body gathers together in the auditorium for an hour-long chapel service.
Outside the classrooms there is year-round spiritually oriented programming that relies on student involvement.
